entry.title: Linearize rhythm: Program that describes how to count polyrhythms
entry.content:
I made a neat tool in a few minutes for analyzing rhythms and find it kind of fascinating.

Main idea

  • The tool lets you write many independent rhythm patterns as input
  • The tool then puts all these patterns together into a multi-voice pattern
    • (as if these patterns were all played over the same duration)
  • This multi-voice pattern makes it easier to play complex rhythms together

The full main.rs can be found in this gist.

Simple example

Ignoring the rest of the program the polyrhythm is hard-coded in the main function.

If we modify the inputs to only contain two patterns we can "explain" a 3/2 polyrhythm

  • We tell the program as input to play a triplet and two-half notes over each other
fn main() {
    let triple =
        AbsolutePatternSingleVoice::new(3, vec![(1, true), (1, true), (1, true)]).unwrap();
    let half = AbsolutePatternSingleVoice::new(2, vec![(1, true), (1, true)]).unwrap();

    let combined_pattern = AbsolutePatternMultipleVoice::from_many(vec![triple, half]);
    println!("{}", combined_pattern);
}
  • The main function will give us an explanation of how to play the pattern including the number of beats
  • And now we can see a simpler way to think about this polyrhythm is the following:
Beats: 6
1: 0 1 
2: 
3: 0 
4: 1 
5: 0 
6:
  • So rather than 3/2 we think 6 beats
  • First beat both voices play
  • Then on beat 3 they do an alternating triplet pattern

Full example

We evenly fit 3 patterns into the same duration of time:

  • 4 notes
  • 3 notes (triplet) with the middle dropped out
  • 2 notes
fn main() {
    let quarter =
        AbsolutePatternSingleVoice::new(4, vec![(1, true), (1, true), (1, true), (1, true)])
            .unwrap();
    let triple =
        AbsolutePatternSingleVoice::new(3, vec![(1, true), (1, false), (1, true)]).unwrap();
    let half = AbsolutePatternSingleVoice::new(2, vec![(1, true), (1, true)]).unwrap();

    let combined_pattern = AbsolutePatternMultipleVoice::from_many(vec![quarter, triple, half]);
    println!("{}", combined_pattern);
}

We get a 12 beat pattern:

Beats: 12
1: 0 1 2 
2: 
3: 
4: 0 
5: 
6: 
7: 0 2 
8: 
9: 1 
10: 0 
11: 
12:
  • Now if you count a measure with 12 beats
  • And play voices 0-2 on the right beats
  • You will be playing the 3 polyrhythms over each other

entry.title: Music player minimalism
entry.content:
After installing Arch Linux and beginning to use it again for the fourth or so time I've given myself a new challenge. Try to eliminate packages that I feel like are unnecessary. I like foobar2000 but it's a Windows program and I only use a small subset of its features. I don't really have a lot of experience with Linux music playing software and have tried to avoid it. Avoiding a proper music player has resulted in me doing some funny things.

The first music player (a shell script)

The idea is to make a shell script that can do at least the following:

  • Recursively find files according to some pattern
  • Loop a list of files
  • Shuffle a list of files
  • Set the volume

I chose gstreamer a multimedia framework for handling the file reading, decoding, playing of audio files which is built around the idea of a configurable pipeline as the method of playing the files.

Here is the source code to play-audio.sh

#!/bin/sh

usage() {
    echo "Usage: $0 <AUDIO_FILE_OR_GLOB> [LOOP=false]|[shuffle] [VOLUME=1.0]"
    echo "Simple GStreamer pipeline to play audio to your default audio output"
    exit 1
}

if [[ $# -eq 0 ]]; then
    usage
fi

loop=0
shuffle=0
file_reorder="sort -z"
if [[ $# -ge 2 ]]; then
    case "$2" in
        loop)
            loop=1
            ;;
        shuffle)
            loop=1
            shuffle=1
            file_reorder="shuf -z"
            ;;
        *)
            usage
    esac
fi

files="$1"
if [[ $1 == *\*** ]]; then
    files="$(find . -name "$1" -type f -print0 | $file_reorder | xargs -n1 -d '\0')"
fi


vol_elem="identity"
if [[ $# -eq 3 ]]; then
    vol_elem="volume volume=$3"
fi

finish() {
    exit 1
}
trap finish INT

while true; do
    # play the playlist
    while IFS= read -r file; do
        echo "Playing $(basename "$file")"
        gst-launch-1.0 --quiet filesrc location="$file" ! decodebin ! audioconvert ! $vol_elem ! autoaudiosink
    done <<< "$files"
    # shuffle the playlist if shuffle is on
    if [[ $shuffle -eq 1 ]]; then
        if [[ $1 == *\*** ]]; then
            files="$(find . -name "$1" -type f -print0 | $file_reorder | xargs -n1 -d '\0')"
        fi
    fi
    [[ $loop -eq 1 ]] || break
done

This solution is pretty good but it has a few large glaring flaws:

  • No way to pause the audio or remember state
  • No playlist controls (skip, previous, etc..)
  • No way to change the volume once a song is playing

The second music player (a daemon)

The idea is to make a daemon that runs in the background and is commanded through a socket

I chose mpv specifically libmpv bindings in Rust as the audio playing backend.

entry.title: Config management from scratch
entry.content:
There is a GNU utility called stow that lets a user manage symlinks. This lets you for example store all of your config files in a folder in your home directory then link them across your system in all the proper places. That in turn will allow you to easily track these files in git for example.

I didn't know this tool existed and I decided that I should make my own and it turned out a bit different.

My solution to deploying configurable config

Revolves around two shell scripts:

  1. link-set
  2. config

And a very simple config file format for modularity

script: link-set

Program to perform two set operations on the filesystem using symlinks:

  1. union
    • Takes a source directory/file and unions (using symlinks) it over the destination directory/file.
    • Now the destination contains all of the files/directories from the source (as symlinks)
    • If conflicting files exist in the destination it will not touch them (because it is a union)
    • Idempotent (only changes if you add more files to the source or use minus)
  2. minus
    • Removes all symlinks that would be created by the union
    • If a file exists that would be symlinked but it is not a symlink it is excluded
    • Only removes the file/dir link if its source is actually symlinked to it
    • Idempotent

config file: a 'linkage'

  • A simple ad hoc file format for linking all the config files for a given program/purpose
  • The purpose of separating the linkages is so that they can be linked/unlinked independently instead of always linking/unlinking the entire system config
  • Linkages can include other linkages (don't make an infinite loop...)

A typical linkage looks like the following: editors.conf

config/.vimrc=~
config/vscode/settings.json=~/.config/Code/User/
config/vscode/customstyle.css=~/.config/Code/User/

On the LHS of the equals sign we specify the source directory and on the RHS we specify the system path (~ is substituted for the users's home directory).

A more complex linkage may link many things together: basic.conf

# Include all of the basic system setup
.include shells.conf
.include editors.conf
.include git.conf
...

Linkage files consist of comments, includes and links:

  • # is a comment
  • .include includes another linkage with your linkage
  • config/dir=/sys/dir links config dir as sys/dir
  • config/file=/sys/dir/ links file into sys/dir
  • config/file=/sys/file links file as sys/file

script: config

The higher-level tool for managing configurations.

  • Either links or unlinks a given linkage
  • All these operations are safe and won't destroy your files

interesting properties of linkages

  • Linking a superset of something you have already linked works fine
  • Unlinking a subset of your linkages works file
  • Linking more than once does nothing unless new config files are added
  • Does not destroy conflicting files the system may have during linking/unlinking
    • this property can be though of as 'overlaying' your config on the system
    • if the system already has its own config it doesn't destroy it
  • Unlinking is painless
  • Can easily swap between multiple different config installs
  • When you link a directory new files placed in it are now in your config folder

How I setup my system now

Basic setup

This is how you get a config repo and install the scripts in your path:

git clone <config_repo>
cd <config repo>/scripts
./config link install # installs the required scripts to your path

The rest of the description assumes you have refreshed your path

Full config install 

config link all     # links all my config in my system

Note: This can be done over any linux system and will not mess up any of its file setup and can be easily installed with

Modular config 

config link nongeneric/sway
config link editors
config link systems/my-system-config

Uninstall

To uninstall an individual component just do it by name:

config unlink editors

To uninstall everything just do uninstall all. It will not fail even if you only have a partially installed config

config unlink all

entry.title: 2025 Learning Topics
entry.content:
Topics

Signal Processing

Since I've been playing with audio processing for fun and often am adjacent to Computer Vision applications at work I've been interested in signal processing.

In general the skill of analyzing data in the frequency domain seems to help one gain intuition for abstract similarities between audio, images or other types of data especially in the time domain.

Resources

  • Mike X Cohen: applied courses for both signal processing, image processing and fourier transform
  • Iain Explains: applied engineering examples of fourier transform

Linear Algebra

I want to improve my intuitions for Linear Algebra and advance into more applied topics. I remember the basics from my undergraduate studies but want to get to more advanced topics which prove to be useful for Signal Processing, Computer Vision, ML and Statistics.

Resources

  • MIT 18.06 Linear Algebra Lectures
  • Linear Algebra Done Right1
  • MIT 18.065: Matrix Methods in Data Analysis, Signal Processing, and Machine Learning

Statistics

A similar story as with Linear Algebra here. I think however with Statistics I could probably take a more theoretical approach as the courses from my undergrad were very applied and I believe my intuition for a topic is usually better when I take a more rigorous approach. Especially given this is second pass through the topic it usually makes sense to try formalizing the concepts.

Resources

  • Statistical Inference Second Edition2
  • All of Statistics3
  • Statistics for Mathematicians: A Rigorous First Course4

Computer Vision

I'm interested in doing a high-level overview of the concepts. I noticed that there are lecture notes from CS484: Introduction to Computer Vision which I will probably try to skim through for a high-level understanding. Understanding signal processing and the frequency domain is a huge aid for jumping into this topic.

Resources

  • Computer Vision: Algorithms and Applications5
  • Concise Computer Vision: An Introduction to Theory and Algorithms6

Analysis

I'd like to study some Analysis to add to my understanding of Calculus fundamentals. I think that it will help with my understanding of statistics/probability and for signal processing.

Resources

  • Analysis 17

Minor Interest

Networks

I want to review the low-level protocol concepts to have a more solid understanding of the fundamentals. I took a course on this: CS456 Computer Networks which did go over things like TCP including the connection state machine.

Resources

  • TCP/IP Illustrated, Volume 1: The Protocols8

LLMs

Continue to play with locally hosted LLMs. Possibly look into more customized models or how to improve my workflow with LLMs.

Books

1

Sheldon Axler, Linear Algebra Done Right, fourth edition

2

George Casella, Roger L. Berger; Statistical Inference Second Edition (978-0534243128)

3

Larry Wasserman, All of Statistics: A Concise Course in Statistical Inference (978-0387402727)

4

Victor M. Panaretos, Statistics for Mathematicians: A Rigorous First Course (978-3319283395)

5

Richard Szeliski, Computer Vision: Algorithms and Applications, 2nd ed.

6

Reinhard Klette, Concise Computer Vision An Introduction to Theory and Algorithms (978-1447163190)

7

Terence Tao, Analysis 1 (978-8185931623)

8

W. Richard Stevens, TCP/IP Illustrated, Volume 1: The Protocols (978-0201633467)
